decoworld.model

Class User

  • java.lang.Object
    • decoworld.model.User

  • @Entity
public class User
extends java.lang.Object
    Model for the user playing in the world. User name, user profile, that kind of thing. Distinct from the model of the player's character. Note: The user model has JPA annotations to allow it to be mapped to relational tables for storage/retrieval using the Hibernate ORM. Each Player has a set 'privilege level' which allows them a certain amount of control over the world, with higher levels allowing greater control. The description of each level is as follows: LEVEL 0: The standard Player privilege level. The Player has basic control in the world. They will be able to interact with world objects such as enemies, items, landmarks, etc. Their interaction with other players will be limited to simple transactions, chatting (including reporting, if they misbehave) and PvP (if applicable). LEVEL 1: The Level 1 Moderator privilege level. The Player now has access to the basic Moderator privileges, which include the ability to immediately teleport to, warn, mute, or temporarily banish another Player from a particular area of the map/dungeon, provided that the Moderator has a higher privilege level than the Player. The Player will also have access to a private "Moderator" chat, which will allow them to communicate with other Moderators, see which Players have been reported or banned (or pending bans) and input special commands. Note: Level 1 Moderators must still adhere to the rules of courtesy in the game and any outright abuse of power can be reported and punished. LEVEL 2: The Level 2 Moderator privilege level. The Player inherits the privileges of the Level 1 Moderator, but is now able to punish Level 1 Moderators for misconduct. In addition, they can also temporarily ban a Player from the server, for up to a week, depending on the severity of the offence of the offending Player. Note: Level 2 Moderators must still adhere to the rules of courtesy in the game and any outright abuse of power can be reported and punished. LEVEL 3: The Level 3 Moderator privilege level. The Player inherits the privileges of the Level 2 Moderator, and is now able to PERMANANTLY ban Players from the game in the special case of severe misconduct of a Player. The Player is also able to punish Level 2 Moderators for misconduct. Note: Level 3 Moderators must still adhere to the rules of courtesy in the game and any outright abuse of power can be reported and punished. LEVEL 4: The Level 4 Moderator privilege level. The Player inherits the privileges of the Level 3 Moderator, and is able to punish Level 3 Moderators for misconduct. The Player is also now able to CREATE new Moderators, up to Level 3 or revoke such privileges as punishment. Note: Level 3 Moderators must still adhere to the rules of courtesy in the game and any outright abuse of power can be reported and punished. LEVEL 5: The Level 5 Moderator privilege level. This is the highest privilege level a Player can have in the game. This level is reserved for a select few Players, such as the System or Server Administrators. The Level 5 Moderators inherit the privileges of the Level 4 Moderator, but are also able to create Level 4 Moderators and other Level 5 Moderators. The Player will also be able to revoke the privileges of up to Level 4 Moderators, but the Server Administrators alone have the power to revoke other Level 5 Moderators. Note: while it is possible to report a Level 5 Moderator, the only Players who will be able to view and action the report will be other Level 5 Moderators, and such a report, unless properly justified, may be punished with a warning or a ban.

      • banValue

        public int banValue
        Specifies whether the Player is banned. Element is of type int and designates duration in seconds. If the int is 0, then player is not banned. If the int is -1 then ban is permanent.

      • banTime

        public java.util.Date banTime

      • muteValue

        public int muteValue
        Specifies whether the Player is muted. Element is of type int and designates duration in seconds. If the int is 0, then player is free to chat. If the int is -1 then mute is permanent.

      • muteTime

        public java.util.Date muteTime

    • Constructor Detail

      • User

        public User()
        The default constructor. Required for Hibernate. Generates a username for the Player and set's the Player's privilege level to the default.

        The User constructor. Assign's the Player's username from the given string and set's the Player's privilege level to the default.
